messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health helped people.
So, fewer children died when they were small.
This made more people live.
The number of people grew fast.
Families had many kids.
These kids grew up.
Then they had their own kids.
But in the 1960s, people could get medicine to stop having babies.
This medicine is called contraception.
So, women had fewer babies.
Before, a woman usually had six babies.
Now, she usually has only two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5965 is significantly below the required 0.75. The text fails to adequately convey the causal relationships and the overall narrative of population growth followed by a decline, which are central to the original meaning. Fidelity Failure: The BERTScore of 0.8937 is below the required 0.90, indicating a loss of key lexical information. This text does not meet the A2 standard for meaning and fidelity.  The CEFR classifier result of A2 is irrelevant as the text failed at a higher priority level.  Specific deviations are listed below:  The original phrase 'fuelling rapid population growth' is not fully captured. Your text states 'This made more people live. The number of people grew fast.' which is descriptive but lacks the strong causal link of 'fuelling'.  The original 'These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children' emphasizes the production of more children contributing to growth. Your version 'Families had many kids. These kids grew up. Then they had their own kids.' loses this emphasis on cumulative growth.  The original 'the global average number of babies per woman has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two' clearly states a decline and a range. Your text 'Before, a woman usually had six babies. Now, she usually has only two babies.' separates these facts, weakening the sense of a direct decline and losing the 'global average' context.  Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to maintain stronger causal connections. Ensure the narrative of growth and subsequent decline is clearly linked. Use more direct comparative language to show the change in birth rates, for example, 'The number of babies per woman went down from six to two across the world.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health helped people.
So, fewer children died young.
This made the number of people grow fast.
Families had many children.
These children grew up.
They had their own children too.
So, the number of people grew even more.
But in the 1960s, people could get medicine to stop having babies.
This medicine is called contraception.
So, women had fewer babies.
The number of babies per woman went down.
It went from six babies to two babies.
This was the average across the world.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6013 is too low, falling significantly below the required 0.75. While the individual facts are present, the overall coherence and strength of the original message's causal links and trends are diminished by the fragmentation and simplification. For example, the original's concise statement 'improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth' is broken into multiple, less causally explicit sentences like 'new machines and better health helped people. So, fewer children died young. This made the number of people grow fast.' This dilutes the direct cause-and-effect relationship. Similarly, the impact of 'has declined from six babies per woman to as low as two' is lessened by being split into several descriptive sentences, losing the strong, direct narrative flow and the emphasis on the magnitude of the change. The text describes events but does not convey the same strong causal and consequential relationships as the original. Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to maintain stronger causal links and emphasize the significance of the population changes, while still adhering to A2 vocabulary and sentence structures. Combine related ideas more directly to preserve the original's semantic density.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health came. Because of this, fewer children died young. So, the number of people grew fast. Families had many children. These children lived and had their own children. This made the number of people grow more.
But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. The average babies per woman went down from six to two. This was across the world.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5718 is unacceptable, falling significantly below the required 0.75. Your version, while stating facts, weakens these crucial connections. Similarly, 'These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children' is simplified in a way that dilutes the direct generational impact. Suggestion: Reconstruct sentences to explicitly reinforce the cause-and-effect relationships and the ongoing process of population change, ensuring the full depth of the original meaning is conveyed within A2 linguistic constraints.

But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. The average number of babies per woman went down. It went from six babies to two babies. This happened all over the world.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5759 is significantly below the required 0.75. While the BERTScore of 0.9097 is acceptable, the core message and causal relationships from the original text have been diluted or lost in simplification. Your version, 'This made the number of people grow fast' and 'Families had many children. These children grew up. They had their own children. Suggestion: Rephrase to explicitly link the survival of children to the *acceleration* of population growth, and ensure the concept of 'fuelling' is conveyed, perhaps by stating that these factors *made* the growth *stronger* or *faster* in a continuous way.

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health helped people. So, fewer children died when they were young. This made the number of people grow very fast. It made the world's population bigger and bigger. Families had many children. These children lived and grew up. Then, these children had their own children. This made the number of people grow even faster.

But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. The average number of babies per woman went down. It went from six babies to two babies. This happened all over the world.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

The simplified version presents these as fragmented, sequential events rather than a cohesive, causal process, thereby losing the depth of the original's explanation of the population boom mechanism. The extreme simplification has sacrificed the nuanced meaning of the original text.

Then, they had their own children. This made the number of people grow very fast. The world's population became much bigger.

But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. The average number of babies per woman went down from six to two. This happened all over the world.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.646 is significantly below the required 0.75. The original text emphasizes 'fuelling rapid population growth' and the self-perpetuating cycle of 'large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children'. Your version describes the sequence of events but loses the strong causal link and the sense of a continuous, reinforcing driver for population increase. messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health helped people. Fewer children died when they were young. So, families had many children who lived. These children grew up. They also had their own children. This caused the number of people to grow very fast. The world's population became much bigger.

But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. The average number of babies per woman went down from six to two. This happened all over the world.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6437 is significantly below the required 0.75. While all factual points are present, the core message regarding the direct mechanism and impact of rapid population growth is diluted by the over-simplification of the causal chain. The original text conveys a strong, self-reinforcing cycle of population growth with phrases like 'fuelling rapid population growth' and 'These large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children.' Your version breaks this into fragmented sentences ('So, families had many children who lived. These children grew up. They also had their own children. This caused the number of people to grow very fast. The world's population became much bigger.'), which loses the directness and emphasis of the original's explanation of how large families directly fueled rapid growth. The sense of a compounding effect is diminished. Suggestion: Rephrase the section on population growth to more directly link the survival of children to the rapid increase in population, maintaining the causal strength of the original. For example, combine sentences to show a clearer cause-and-effect, such as 'Fewer children died, so families grew big. These big families had many children who also lived and had their own children. This made the number of people grow very fast.'

Text saved: In the past, new machines and better health helped people. Fewer children died young. This made the world's population grow very fast. Families became large. These large families had more children. These children also lived and had their own children.

But in the 1960s, people could get contraception. This is medicine to stop having babies. So, women had fewer babies. Before, women had six babies on average. Now, they have two babies on average. This happened all over the world.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6791 is below the required 0.75. The original text conveys a stronger causal link and a more precise description of the population change. The phrase 'fuelling rapid population growth' implies a continuous and direct cause-and-effect that is somewhat diluted by breaking it into separate sentences like 'Fewer children died young. This made the world's population grow very fast.' While factually correct, the nuance of the mechanism is softened. Additionally, 'declined from six babies per woman to as low as two' is a more direct and precise description of the change than stating the 'before' and 'now' numbers separately, which slightly reduces the fidelity of the 'decline' concept. Suggestion: Rephrase to maintain the strong causal connection of 'fuelling' and the directness of 'declined'. For example, 'fewer children died, which made the population grow fast' or 'the number of babies went down from six to two'.
